page.title: 01Kessingland and its environs
page.content: Over half this block is in the North Sea. The rest consists of agricultural land enclosing a stretch of cliffs and the coastal village of Kessingland. The extreme southern edge drops gently to a marshy, reeded area. Kessingland is on the A12 trunk road linking Great Yarmouth to the north with Ipswich to the south. A quiet village, it relies heavily on tourism, the population of approximately 3880 doubling in summer. There are numerous chalet, caravan and camping sits in the area, the largest complex offering around 200 accomodation units. The extensive shingle beach carries 200-30 small fishing boats from which Cod, Herring, Spratts, Plaice and Shrimps are caught. The small farms which surround Kessingland produce crops of wheat, barley,corn, sugarbeet
